content.description: SDS on the far right then traverse left along the jugs/rail all the way to the left.  Practice your mantling skills or burnout the forearms.  Either way it's just a warm up / workout boulder.
content.location: This is really the boulder to the right of "The Line" but it's really the same type. It's to the right of the rock that's been charred by a campfire.

content.description: Small sequence of grabs on the right end of the boulder starting with hands doubled on a thick flake and a heel hook on a smaller flake. Grab the flat rail then make a short dyno to the juggy slot.
content.location: On the right side of The Line.  It starts low near the large pine tree.

climbs.name: I walk with a crimp cuz my nuts heavy

content.description: Starts same as myanmar and goes left along crimpy rail and then throw to juggy rail.
Sit start with a pair of sharp crimps, dyno left hand to an improbable sloper, keep your feet on, then grab a tiny crimp with right hand and top out.
content.protection: There's a decent sized rock in the landing, you'll want a pad.
content.location: On the smaller, right overhang that also houses Next In Line. The problem is on the left side of the wall.

content.description: Starts matched on a good hold at the far left with your feet on the adjacent boulder. Head up and right utilizing some tricky footwork to a slopey, but easy topout with good feet out right.  A bit contrived,  but a lot of fun none the less.
content.location: The furthest left piece of rock at The Line.

content.description:
To the right of Dab Factory on The Line. 

 Start on orange flake and dyno straight up to lip. Mantle up.Â
content.location: To the right of Dab Factory and just to the right of two small trees growing on the lip.

content.description: A long thin line of sharply overhung rock found to the right of The Brain at the top tier of boulders.  The beginning (left side) of this area is marred by what must have been a huge bonfire (not allowed here!).  There are several opportunities for routes here.  Most would be 2-3 moves or traverses on crimpy holds.  The topouts are only maybe 6 feet off the ground so most of the work is done very close to the ground.
